content: In the USA Today newspaper this morning I was reading a cover story about a man who will retire from GM in two years. He is so happy. He is locked in to work with pay even though he may not have to go to work. He makes more than $100.000 an year($29.81/hr. with benefits) Thats more than $40,000 a year more than an E-8 with 20 years in our military. He will retire making more than $3,000 a month. Again more than an E-8 with 20 years in. Not bad for someone with a high school education that works on an assembly line with only about 3 weeks of training. Now can you really feel sorry for him or GM?
reply: In the USA Today newspaper this morning I was reading a cover story about a man who will retire from GM in two years. He is so happy. He is locked in to work with pay even though he may not have to go to work. He makes more than $100.000 an year($29.81/hr. with benefits) Thats more than $40,000 a year more than an E-8 with 20 years in our military. He will retire making more than $3,000 a month. Again more than an E-8 with 20 years in. Not bad for someone with a high school education that works on an assembly line with only about 3 weeks of training. Now can you really feel sorry for him or GM?
title: Should we feel sorry for GM?

content: Whatever the market can bear. Right now it can't bear much. It's foolishness that cars went to $30,000.00 a copy, but we all bought them at that and fueled the stupidity. Is he wrong for taking what he can get? Not if he got it honestly over the table. Wrong to compare him to a military rank. Apples and Oranges... The guy produces a product that rolls down the road and fuels the economy. Military and Civil Service consume with no return. A society can only pay for so much of that before it breaks itself. That is part of the problem too. There probably as many people on federal payroll as there are in all other jobs combined. So your auto worker, and all his co-workers have to pay a lot of taxes to keep that E-8 in a job that doesn't roll a visible product down the street. When I was an E-6, I pulled down about $500.00 a month before taxes, but it was consider "service", instead of an occupation. Everybody will have to suffer some cuts and bad times for this economy to balance out at some kind of reality. GM builds a good car, but their company and the government's various employees are all paid way too much for the market to bear, so it's sliding down and down until it finds a level where it can float. No reason to hate GM or want it to fail. If you like Chevys, buy a little one or a used one. As long as the money flows a little for parts and product, the core of the company will find a way to survive if it wants to. No, I'm not a military-basher, and I have a son who is an E-8 (Air Force). Wandering and Wondering
reply: Whatever the market can bear. Right now it can't bear much. It's foolishness that cars went to $30,000.00 a copy, but we all bought them at that and fueled the stupidity. content: Well I thought seriously about a new truck when they first started running the deals. Problem is, they do not offer one without all the bells and whistles any more. I don't want electric seats, windows and locks. Nore do I want carpet or an automatic tranny. It is a truck, not a luxury car. Being they don't offer what I want, I will stick to the one I have.

I don't want electric seats, windows and locks. Nore do I want carpet or an automatic tranny. It is a truck, not a luxury car. Being they don't offer what I want, I will stick to the one I have.
title: Should we feel sorry for GM?

content: Mike, My 22 year-old JEEP is all I can afford, but it gets better mileage than any of the POS on the market today. I guess I'll keep putting oil in it. Nope, don't feel sorry for 'em. They saw the writing on the wall in that industry in the early '70s and nobody did squat. Let 'em fail.
reply: Mike, My 22 year-old JEEP is all I can afford, but it gets better mileage than any of the POS on the market today. I guess I'll keep putting oil in it. Nope, don't feel sorry for 'em. They saw the writing on the wall in that industry in the early '70s and nobody did squat. Let 'em fail.
title: Should we feel sorry for GM?

content: From what I've read from a friend working in a unionized (UAW) auto parts plant: "New hires wages were reduced to $14/hour many years ago. A few years ago even senior workers were given lump sums to have their pay reduced to the same as new hires. New hires do not get pensions and have minimum benefits. The UAW negotiated with the car plants to have their health care turned over to them and will no longer be provided through the company, to take effect in another year. Also line workers at GM hire in at the same $14 wages, this was negotiated in their last contract."
reply: From what I've read from a friend working in a unionized (UAW) auto parts plant: "New hires wages were reduced to $14/hour many years ago. A few years ago even senior workers were given lump sums to have their pay reduced to the same as new hires. New hires do not get pensions and have minimum benefits. The UAW negotiated with the car plants to have their health care turned over to them and will no longer be provided through the company, to take effect in another year. Also line workers at GM hire in at the same $14 wages, this was negotiated in their last contract."
title: Should we feel sorry for GM?

content: Realistically, unless your a hopeless Union-fanatic, you can't feel sorry GM. Sure, you can feel sorry for all those families who be affected by the loss of jobs, but not for the manufacturer. IF they couldn't take the hint, back in the late 70's, when Honda became the #1 selling car in America (first time a foreign auto could claim this), then WHY cry for them now?? It's just p-poor business, to declair loss of profit, and award the High-ranking execs multi-million dollar bonuses! Of course, seeing this, the Union jumps on the band-wagon, and demands their cut, only part of which goes to the worker!! Who pays?? The idiots who buy into the wghole brand-loyalty schemes which ALL of the "big three" throw out to the masses. As they continue to cry loss of profit, get FAR richer in the process, and FLEECE the American consumer. "Buy America, FOR America" was originally meant to stimulate and benefit ALL Americans. NOT just the upper 1% controlling big business! Those who tout the thinking of "skru everyone to fill my own pockets" should be treated like the criminals they are!!! Even those in the auto industry.

content: quote: Originally posted by Woody_in_La: Well I thought seriously about a new truck when they first started running the deals. Problem is, they do not offer one without all the bells and whistles any more. I don't want electric seats, windows and locks. Funny...I traded in my 2003 Dodge Ram 1500 for a 2008 Ford F-150. The Ram didn't have power windows and it drove me nuts having to reach into the back seat to open or close the rear window every time my German Shepherd decided he wanted to hang his head out the window. If I ever ignore him, he'll start poking at my shoulder with his nose. "Yo bossman...open the damn window!" Don

If I ever ignore him, he'll start poking at my shoulder with his nose. "Yo bossman...open the damn window!" Don

content: I have mixed feelings about the car companys. I have relatives that are directly affected both at GM and at Chrysler and I dont want them to suffer. At the same time I can see where my money to save them isn't right, they wont be bailing me out when things go bad for me. Only 10% of the cost of a car is the labor to build it. They need to nock down that other 90% Shockey

content: quote: Originally posted by Woody_in_La: Well I thought seriously about a new truck when they first started running the deals. Problem is, they do not offer one without all the bells and whistles any more. I don't want electric seats, windows and locks. Nore do I want carpet or an automatic tranny. It is a truck, not a luxury car. Being they don't offer what I want, I will stick to the one I have. I like your thinking. People that want work trucks should not have to buy one with a bunch of crap they don't want. Over the years a large proportion of truck sales have changed from work vehicles to pleasure vehicles. I don't own a truck and don't want one. The two or three times a year I need a truck I just rent one but it seems like people want trucks regardless if they ever haul stuff in them or not. Looking at it from another angle it must be realized that dealers make a very big profit on accessories. It's to their advantage to stock product that's "loaded." A friend of mine recently bought a new Honda Civic. The dealer tried to charge him $295.00 for floor mats, a trunk liner and four wheel locks! My friend asked the salesman if he had the word stupid tattooed on his forehead. The salesman took the $295.00 charge off the contract and didn't even bother having the stuff taken off the car. Just as an aside,the Honda Civic is a fine, well built car that has about the best trade in value there is but I've been in tanks that rode better. How come I pressed "One for English" and still can't understand a word the dude is saying?

It is a truck, not a luxury car. Being they don't offer what I want, I will stick to the one I have.

content: Yep, I liked how pick ups used to be. A motor, brakes, steel body, heater, optional turn signals. All for under $10,000. A basic tough vehicle.
reply: Yep, I liked how pick ups used to be. A motor, brakes, steel body, heater, optional turn signals. All for under $10,000. A basic tough vehicle.
title: Should we feel sorry for GM?

content: I'm torn between feeling sorry for GM and feeling they brought it on themselves. I don't blame the unions as much as the excutives of the companies! The executives incomes are in the millions, lets not forget the excutives flew in company owned aircraft to DC for the meeting with congress to ask for a bailout. The same executives get multi-million dollar golden parachutes when they leave the companies. They join another company and are paid millions by the company who just hired them. So they have a multi-million dollar golden parachute from one company and a multi-million dollar income from the company they now are with. Whats wrong with this picture? Corperate greed comes to mind. American car manufacturers cut corners to keep costs down so they can keep profits up while quality goes down! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
reply: I'm torn between feeling sorry for GM and feeling they brought it on themselves. I don't blame the unions as much as the excutives of the companies! The executives incomes are in the millions, lets not forget the excutives flew in company owned aircraft to DC for the meeting with congress to ask for a bailout. The same executives get multi-million dollar golden parachutes when they leave the companies. They join another company and are paid millions by the company who just hired them. So they have a multi-million dollar golden parachute from one company and a multi-million dollar income from the company they now are with. Whats wrong with this picture? Corperate greed comes to mind. American car manufacturers cut corners to keep costs down so they can keep profits up while quality goes down! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!

content: quote: Originally posted by shockey: I have mixed feelings about the car companys. I have relatives that are directly affected both at GM and at Chrysler and I dont want them to suffer. At the same time I can see where my money to save them isn't right, they wont be bailing me out when things go bad for me. Only 10% of the cost of a car is the labor to build it. They need to nock down that other 90% Shockey That 10% is in the assembly plants. The labor to create the parts that are used in the assembly are not counted in that number. Most manufacturing plants out sourced those labor intensitive and skilled jobs years ago. Lots of the parts are made by retired UAW workers now operating as independent contractors with contracts to supply parts to the big three. Many of these plants are just assembly buildings with very few of the parts made in the building. They are all trucked in just in time to be assembled into cars. The number of small businesses that will be hurt temporally until another business picks up the new car neeed. Replacement parts needs will triple in the next 5 years since many will keep their cars and the small businesses will produce part for Napa and others. Junk yard dealers will benifit and body shops since it will be benifitial to repair the old vehicle than total it.

They need to nock down that other 90% Shockey

content: Do not forget the government regulations for safety sake that has contributed to the cost of the vehicles and the milage requirements that cast money and a big payment to the government for "gas guzzeler tax" Do you realize that every vehicle manufactured that gets 16 miles to the gallon the manufacturer pays an exise tax to the government of $7,500. This tax goes down as the milage goes to 22 miles a gallon where it is nothing. Yes the government has a big stake in keeping the milage down. Many parts of the auto are exise taxed by the government as are all your arrows you buy to hunt with. Gert Pub 720 IRS and you will be stunned on what is taxed. A OTR Semi is taxed 12 % of selling price direct to the treasury.

content: I'm gonna step on some toes, but I don't care. The unions got the auto makers in the fix they are in and I say NO more money. What good is it going to do but hold them up for a couple more months and then they are going to come back crying with their hand out. Let them go down, get rid of the unions, start building a GOOD product, that the American peolpe can rely on lasting longer than five years, and then I might worry about it. NO MORE MONEY> There is only one thing worse than messing an old fart, and that is messing with two.

content: no, i dont feel bad. if i file bankruptcy i would have to return all my toys and hopefully keep my house and car. but look at the airlines.. they lay a few people off and continue with business as well. if i cant afford to pay my house and car, you think anyones going to bail me out?
reply: no, i dont feel bad. if i file bankruptcy i would have to return all my toys and hopefully keep my house and car. but look at the airlines.. they lay a few people off and continue with business as well. if i cant afford to pay my house and car, you think anyones going to bail me out?
title: Should we feel sorry for GM?

content: quote: Even during a layoff, they make about 80% of their check. Not now, they don't. I think they did away with the "job pool". So I guess every tub sits on its own bottom now.
quote: Even during a layoff, they make about 80% of their check.
reply: Not now, they don't. I think they did away with the "job pool". So I guess every tub sits on its own bottom now.
title: Should we feel sorry for GM?

content: Mike, My 22 year-old JEEP is all I can afford, but it gets better mileage than any of the POS on the market today. I guess I'll keep putting oil in it. Nope, don't feel sorry for 'em. They saw the writing on the wall in that industry in the early '70s and nobody did squat. Let 'em fail.
reply: Mike, My 22 year-old JEEP is all I can afford, but it gets better mileage than any of the POS on the market today. I guess I'll keep putting oil in it. Nope, don't feel sorry for 'em. They saw the writing on the wall in that industry in the early '70s and nobody did squat. Let 'em fail.
title: Should we feel sorry for GM?

content: From what I've read from a friend working in a unionized (UAW) auto parts plant: "New hires wages were reduced to $14/hour many years ago. A few years ago even senior workers were given lump sums to have their pay reduced to the same as new hires. New hires do not get pensions and have minimum benefits. The UAW negotiated with the car plants to have their health care turned over to them and will no longer be provided through the company, to take effect in another year. Also line workers at GM hire in at the same $14 wages, this was negotiated in their last contract."
reply: From what I've read from a friend working in a unionized (UAW) auto parts plant: "New hires wages were reduced to $14/hour many years ago. A few years ago even senior workers were given lump sums to have their pay reduced to the same as new hires. New hires do not get pensions and have minimum benefits. The UAW negotiated with the car plants to have their health care turned over to them and will no longer be provided through the company, to take effect in another year. Also line workers at GM hire in at the same $14 wages, this was negotiated in their last contract."
title: Should we feel sorry for GM?

content: Realistically, unless your a hopeless Union-fanatic, you can't feel sorry GM. Sure, you can feel sorry for all those families who be affected by the loss of jobs, but not for the manufacturer. IF they couldn't take the hint, back in the late 70's, when Honda became the #1 selling car in America (first time a foreign auto could claim this), then WHY cry for them now?? It's just p-poor business, to declair loss of profit, and award the High-ranking execs multi-million dollar bonuses! Of course, seeing this, the Union jumps on the band-wagon, and demands their cut, only part of which goes to the worker!! Who pays?? The idiots who buy into the wghole brand-loyalty schemes which ALL of the "big three" throw out to the masses. As they continue to cry loss of profit, get FAR richer in the process, and FLEECE the American consumer. "Buy America, FOR America" was originally meant to stimulate and benefit ALL Americans. NOT just the upper 1% controlling big business! Those who tout the thinking of "skru everyone to fill my own pockets" should be treated like the criminals they are!!! Even those in the auto industry.

IF they couldn't take the hint, back in the late 70's, when Honda became the #1 selling car in America (first time a foreign auto could claim this), then WHY cry for them now?? It's just p-poor business, to declair loss of profit, and award the High-ranking execs multi-million dollar bonuses! NOT just the upper 1% controlling big business! Those who tout the thinking of "skru everyone to fill my own pockets" should be treated like the criminals they are!!! Even those in the auto industry.

content: quote: Originally posted by Woody_in_La: Well I thought seriously about a new truck when they first started running the deals. Problem is, they do not offer one without all the bells and whistles any more. I don't want electric seats, windows and locks. Funny...I traded in my 2003 Dodge Ram 1500 for a 2008 Ford F-150. The Ram didn't have power windows and it drove me nuts having to reach into the back seat to open or close the rear window every time my German Shepherd decided he wanted to hang his head out the window. If I ever ignore him, he'll start poking at my shoulder with his nose. "Yo bossman...open the damn window!" Don
quote: Originally posted by Woody_in_La: Well I thought seriously about a new truck when they first started running the deals. Problem is, they do not offer one without all the bells and whistles any more. I don't want electric seats, windows and locks.

If I ever ignore him, he'll start poking at my shoulder with his nose. "Yo bossman...open the damn window!" Don
title: Should we feel sorry for GM?

content: I have mixed feelings about the car companys. I have relatives that are directly affected both at GM and at Chrysler and I dont want them to suffer. At the same time I can see where my money to save them isn't right, they wont be bailing me out when things go bad for me. Only 10% of the cost of a car is the labor to build it. They need to nock down that other 90% Shockey
reply: I have mixed feelings about the car companys. I have relatives that are directly affected both at GM and at Chrysler and I dont want them to suffer. At the same time I can see where my money to save them isn't right, they wont be bailing me out when things go bad for me. Only 10% of the cost of a car is the labor to build it. They need to nock down that other 90% Shockey
title: Should we feel sorry for GM?

content: quote: Originally posted by Woody_in_La: Well I thought seriously about a new truck when they first started running the deals. Problem is, they do not offer one without all the bells and whistles any more. I don't want electric seats, windows and locks. Nore do I want carpet or an automatic tranny. It is a truck, not a luxury car. Being they don't offer what I want, I will stick to the one I have. I like your thinking. People that want work trucks should not have to buy one with a bunch of crap they don't want. Over the years a large proportion of truck sales have changed from work vehicles to pleasure vehicles. I don't own a truck and don't want one. The two or three times a year I need a truck I just rent one but it seems like people want trucks regardless if they ever haul stuff in them or not. Looking at it from another angle it must be realized that dealers make a very big profit on accessories. It's to their advantage to stock product that's "loaded." A friend of mine recently bought a new Honda Civic. The dealer tried to charge him $295.00 for floor mats, a trunk liner and four wheel locks! My friend asked the salesman if he had the word stupid tattooed on his forehead. The salesman took the $295.00 charge off the contract and didn't even bother having the stuff taken off the car. Just as an aside,the Honda Civic is a fine, well built car that has about the best trade in value there is but I've been in tanks that rode better. How come I pressed "One for English" and still can't understand a word the dude is saying?
quote: Originally posted by Woody_in_La: Well I thought seriously about a new truck when they first started running the deals. It is a truck, not a luxury car. Being they don't offer what I want, I will stick to the one I have.
reply: I like your thinking. People that want work trucks should not have to buy one with a bunch of crap they don't want. Over the years a large proportion of truck sales have changed from work vehicles to pleasure vehicles. I don't own a truck and don't want one. The two or three times a year I need a truck I just rent one but it seems like people want trucks regardless if they ever haul stuff in them or not. Looking at it from another angle it must be realized that dealers make a very big profit on accessories. It's to their advantage to stock product that's "loaded." A friend of mine recently bought a new Honda Civic. The dealer tried to charge him $295.00 for floor mats, a trunk liner and four wheel locks! My friend asked the salesman if he had the word stupid tattooed on his forehead. The salesman took the $295.00 charge off the contract and didn't even bother having the stuff taken off the car. Just as an aside,the Honda Civic is a fine, well built car that has about the best trade in value there is but I've been in tanks that rode better. How come I pressed "One for English" and still can't understand a word the dude is saying?

content: Yep, I liked how pick ups used to be. A motor, brakes, steel body, heater, optional turn signals. All for under $10,000. A basic tough vehicle.
reply: Yep, I liked how pick ups used to be. A motor, brakes, steel body, heater, optional turn signals. All for under $10,000. A basic tough vehicle.
title: Should we feel sorry for GM?

content: I'm torn between feeling sorry for GM and feeling they brought it on themselves. I don't blame the unions as much as the excutives of the companies! The executives incomes are in the millions, lets not forget the excutives flew in company owned aircraft to DC for the meeting with congress to ask for a bailout. The same executives get multi-million dollar golden parachutes when they leave the companies. They join another company and are paid millions by the company who just hired them. So they have a multi-million dollar golden parachute from one company and a multi-million dollar income from the company they now are with. Whats wrong with this picture? Corperate greed comes to mind. American car manufacturers cut corners to keep costs down so they can keep profits up while quality goes down! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
reply: I'm torn between feeling sorry for GM and feeling they brought it on themselves. I don't blame the unions as much as the excutives of the companies! The executives incomes are in the millions, lets not forget the excutives flew in company owned aircraft to DC for the meeting with congress to ask for a bailout. The same executives get multi-million dollar golden parachutes when they leave the companies. They join another company and are paid millions by the company who just hired them. So they have a multi-million dollar golden parachute from one company and a multi-million dollar income from the company they now are with. Whats wrong with this picture? Corperate greed comes to mind. American car manufacturers cut corners to keep costs down so they can keep profits up while quality goes down! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
title: Should we feel sorry for GM?

content: quote: Originally posted by shockey: I have mixed feelings about the car companys. I have relatives that are directly affected both at GM and at Chrysler and I dont want them to suffer. At the same time I can see where my money to save them isn't right, they wont be bailing me out when things go bad for me. Only 10% of the cost of a car is the labor to build it. They need to nock down that other 90% Shockey That 10% is in the assembly plants. The labor to create the parts that are used in the assembly are not counted in that number. Most manufacturing plants out sourced those labor intensitive and skilled jobs years ago. Lots of the parts are made by retired UAW workers now operating as independent contractors with contracts to supply parts to the big three. Many of these plants are just assembly buildings with very few of the parts made in the building. They are all trucked in just in time to be assembled into cars. The number of small businesses that will be hurt temporally until another business picks up the new car neeed. Replacement parts needs will triple in the next 5 years since many will keep their cars and the small businesses will produce part for Napa and others. Junk yard dealers will benifit and body shops since it will be benifitial to repair the old vehicle than total it.
quote: Originally posted by shockey: I have mixed feelings about the car companys. I have relatives that are directly affected both at GM and at Chrysler and I dont want them to suffer. They need to nock down that other 90% Shockey

Most manufacturing plants out sourced those labor intensitive and skilled jobs years ago. Lots of the parts are made by retired UAW workers now operating as independent contractors with contracts to supply parts to the big three. Many of these plants are just assembly buildings with very few of the parts made in the building. They are all trucked in just in time to be assembled into cars. The number of small businesses that will be hurt temporally until another business picks up the new car neeed. content: Do not forget the government regulations for safety sake that has contributed to the cost of the vehicles and the milage requirements that cast money and a big payment to the government for "gas guzzeler tax" Do you realize that every vehicle manufactured that gets 16 miles to the gallon the manufacturer pays an exise tax to the government of $7,500. This tax goes down as the milage goes to 22 miles a gallon where it is nothing. Yes the government has a big stake in keeping the milage down. Many parts of the auto are exise taxed by the government as are all your arrows you buy to hunt with. Gert Pub 720 IRS and you will be stunned on what is taxed. A OTR Semi is taxed 12 % of selling price direct to the treasury.
reply: Do not forget the government regulations for safety sake that has contributed to the cost of the vehicles and the milage requirements that cast money and a big payment to the government for "gas guzzeler tax" Do you realize that every vehicle manufactured that gets 16 miles to the gallon the manufacturer pays an exise tax to the government of $7,500. content: quote: He makes more than $100.000 an year($29.81/hr. with benefits) Thats more than $40,000 a year more than an E-8 with 20 years in our military. Are you comparing the GM employee's pay including the value of benefits (health care) to: An E-8 not including the value of benefits (food, housing, health care), or An E-8 including the value of benefits? Just trying to clarify what we are comparing.

content: I'm gonna step on some toes, but I don't care. The unions got the auto makers in the fix they are in and I say NO more money. What good is it going to do but hold them up for a couple more months and then they are going to come back crying with their hand out. Let them go down, get rid of the unions, start building a GOOD product, that the American peolpe can rely on lasting longer than five years, and then I might worry about it. NO MORE MONEY> There is only one thing worse than messing an old fart, and that is messing with two.
